titleScreen.titleScreenIntroduction: The truth reveals itself only to those who seek it—prepare to set sail on an enlightening adventure, truth-seeker!

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
What is a “Source”?

A source is where information comes from — articles, posts, videos, websites, images, reports, organizations, or people.
Criteria for Reliable Sources

1. Authority - Who Created This?

Ask:

  • Is the author/creator identified?
  • Do they have expertise, credentials, or a clear role?
  • Is the organization reputable?

Anonymous or unclear authorship is a red flag.
Criteria for Reliable Sources

2. Accuracy — Is the information supported by evidence?

Ask:

  • Does it provide facts, data, or sources?
  • Are claims backed up by evidence, or are they just asserted?
  • Did it undergo rigorous checking process?

If it sounds factual but presents no proof → unreliable.
Criteria for Reliable Sources

3. Currency — Is it up-to-date and still relevant?

Ask:

  • When was this published?
  • Is it outdated, missing new details, or referencing old events?
  • For breaking news, has updated information been released?

Old information isn’t always false — but it can be misleading.
Criteria for Reliable Sources

4. Purpose — Why does this exist?

Ask:

  • To inform? entertain? convince? sell? provoke?
  • Is the tone emotional or sensational?
  • Is the post trying to shock you or trigger strong reactions?

Content made to manipulate emotion is more likely to distort facts.
Criteria for Reliable Sources

5. Transparency — Is it clear how the information was produced?

Ask:

  • Are sources cited or linked?
  • Can you see where the data came from?
  • Does the source explain its methods?

Reliable sources show how they reached conclusions. Unreliable ones hide the process.
Criteria for Reliable Sources

6. Verification — Can you confirm it elsewhere?

Ask:

  • Do multiple reputable sources report the same thing?
  • Is the image found somewhere else?
  • Does reverse image search reveal the original context?

If only one sketchy page claims something big → red flag.
Criteria for Reliable Sources

7. Presentation Quality — Does it look professionally made?

Ask:

  • Are there many spelling errors, overuse of punctuation marks, clickbait headlines, or aggressive ads?
  • Is the layout messy or suspicious?
  • Does it mimic a real source but with a strange URL or additional extensions?

Poor-quality presentation can be a common indicator of unreliable content, but watch out for professional looking content that mimics official ones.
Criteria for Reliable Sources

8. Consistency — Does the information align with known facts?

Ask:

  • Does the content match other credible sources on the same topic?
  • Are all parts of the story internally coherent, or do details contradict each other?
  • Are numbers, dates, locations, or events consistent and plausible?

Contradictions, implausible claims, or statements that conflict with trusted sources are red flags.
Tell-Tale Signs of Unreliable Sources

1. No Author / Anonymous

  • No name or organization.
  • Impossible to verify who wrote it.

2. Lack of Evidence

  • Statements are broad, unsupported, or vague.
  • No citations, no links, no sources.
Tell-Tale Signs of Unreliable Sources

3. Emotional Manipulation

  • Uses fear, anger, shock, or outrage to push a message.
  • Headlines designed to provoke and go viral.

4. Inconsistencies

  • Contradictory details.
  • Claims that conflict with established facts.
Tell-Tale Signs of Unreliable Sources

5. Clickbait Headlines

  • Title doesn’t match the body of the article.
  • Uses phrases like “You won’t BELIEVE…” or “Shocking!!!”

6. No Contact Information or About Page

  • Zero transparency about the organization.
  • Fake or unreachable contact info.
  • No editorial or corrections policy.
Tell-Tale Signs of Unreliable Sources

7. Overly Biased or One-Sided

  • Ignores key context or opposing viewpoints.
  • Uses loaded or judgemental language (e.g., “only idiots believe…”).

8. Dubious or Unsecured URLs

  • Strange endings (.buzz, .info, .lo) used for spammy sites.
  • No HTTPS (no padlock symbol).

metadata.title: Instruction: Place reliable sources in the glowing chest, and unreliable sources in the gloomy chest.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Follow Digital Footprints & Trace Information Back to Its Origin

When rumors spread online, they often leave clues behind — images, dates, links, usernames, captions, and screenshots.

Your mission is to track those clues uphill until you find:

  • Where the image or claim first appeared
  • Who originally posted it
  • Whether the source is credible or suspicious

This helps you figure out if a post is accurate, misleading, or completely fake.

1. Reverse-Search Image/s

Sometimes an image used in a post is not from the event it claims to show.
It might be:

  • from a different country
  • from a different year
  • edited
  • or taken out of context
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

What to do:

Use any reverse image search tool:

  • Google Lens
  • TinEye
  • Bing Visual Search
  • Yandex Images (sometimes finds older versions)

What to look for:

  • When does the image appear earliest online?
  • Was it used in news from a different event?
  • Does it appear with different captions elsewhere?

If the origin contradicts the post, that’s a red flag.
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

2. Trace the Claim Back to the First Source

Rumors often get copied, reposted, screenshot, and forwarded — losing their original context. That's why it's very important that you know how to trace a piece of information to its origins.
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

What to do:

1. Check the Post Itself First

Before searching anywhere else, inspect the post for clues. Look for:

  • Date of posting
  • Username or page name
  • Tags or hashtags
  • Links in the caption
  • Screenshots of another post (hint: it’s not original)

This helps you see if the post is original or repurposed.
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

What to do:

2. Search the Exact Sentence or Key Phrases

Copy a unique sentence or phrase from the post and paste it into your browser.

What to do:

  • Put quotation marks around it → " "
  • Try searching only keywords if exact phrases get no results
  • Use filters (Tools → Time → Past week/month/year)

If other people said it earlier, Google will show it.
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

What to do:

3. Use Social Media Filters 

On Facebook, X, TikTok:

  • Search keywords in the search bar
  • Filter by Latest or Date posted
  • Look at the earliest version you can find
  • Check who first said it
  • Compare captions, images, or context
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

Check who first shared it

  • Anonymous page
  • Troll/meme account
  • Newly made accounts
  • “Community groups” with no admins listed

    → These are not trustworthy origins.

Was it journalists, experts, or official agencies?

Reliable claims usually start from:

  • government agencies
  • legitimate news outlets
  • experts with verified profiles

If the rumor starts from a random page, it’s likely unreliable.
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

3. Check What Other Trusted Sources Say

Once you find the earliest version of the rumor:

Ask:

  • Do credible outlets also report it?
  • Does the official organization mentioned confirm it?
  • Is the “proof” only a screenshot with no link?

If trusted sources don’t verify it, it’s likely unreliable — even if widely shared.
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

What If Nothing Comes Up?

Sometimes:

  • the rumor is very new
  • the photo is low-resolution
  • the image was generated (AI)
  • or the claim is too vague
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

What If Nothing Comes Up?

If you cannot trace the image or claim:

  • Do not assume it’s true.
  • Label it as “unverified”
  • Check if fact-checking organizations have looked into it.

Not finding a trail is also a clue.
STEPS YOU CAN TAKE

A post is suspicious if:

  • its image comes from a different event
  • the claim cannot be traced to a credible origin
  • the first sharer is anonymous
  • reverse-search results come out different from the post
  • no reputable source has covered it
What to Watch Out for

A post is more reliable if:

  • the image and claim match the earliest credible posting
  • the original source is reputable
  • other trustworthy sources confirm it
What to Watch Out for

params.text:
What Is Fact-Checking?

Fact-checking is the process of investigating a claim, gathering evidence from trustworthy sources, and determining whether the claim is:

  • True
  • Misleading
  • Needs context
  • False

International Fact-Checking Network Standards

Professional fact-checkers follow strict standards:

  • They are transparent regarding sources, methodology, funding and organization
  • They remain nonpartisan and fair
  • They correct errors openly

IFCN-accredited organizations commit to these standards.

Trusted Fact-Checkers in the Philippines

A. Vera Files Fact Check

IFCN Verified Signatory

Focuses on:

  • Debunking political claims
  • Detecting flip-flops
  • Debunking misleading statements of public officials

Trusted Fact-Checkers in the Philippines

B. Rappler Fact Check

IFCN Verified Signatory

Focuses on:

  • Viral social media posts
  • False images/videos
  • Breaking down inaccuracies

Trusted Fact-Checkers in the Philippines

C. AFP Fact Check (Agence France-Presse Philippines)

IFCN Verified Signatory

Focuses on:

  • Viral content across Asia
  • Misused videos and images
  • False claims about disasters, health, politics

Strength: Excellent at catching fake photos and out-of-context images.

Trusted Fact-Checkers in the Philippines

D. ABS-CBN Fact Check

IFCN Verified Signatory

Focuses on:

  • Viral posts
  • Political claims
  • False statements

Trusted Fact-Checkers in the Philippines

E. PressOne.PH Fact Check

IFCN Verified Signatory

Focuses on:

  • Political misinformation
  • Claims circulating in news and social media
  • Fact-checks of quotes and public figures

Trusted Fact-Checkers in the Philippines

F. MindaNews Fact Check

IFCN Verified Signatory

Focuses on:

  • Mindanao-related misinformation
  • Viral news and social media posts
  • Recycled news

STEPS

1. Search for the key information 

  • Type the suspicious claim, headline, or quote + “fact check” in your browser; or
  • Search directly on the website of Vera Files, Rappler, AFP, etc.
HOW TO DO A FACT-CHECK?

STEPS

2. Read the rating

Example verdicts:

  • False
  • Misleading
  • Needs Context

• Altered
  • No Basis
  • True
HOW TO DO A FACT-CHECK?

STEPS

3. Understand the reasoning

Look for:

  • Where the fact-checkers got evidence
  • Whether experts were consulted
  • What the original source was
  • Why the image/video is misleading
HOW TO DO A FACT-CHECK?

STEPS

4. Submit suspicious content

You can also submit or report questionable posts to be fact-checked if not enough information is available about them.

All of these organizations accept submissions:

  • Rappler → Email submission
  • Vera Files → Messenger tip line
  • AFP → Contact form

• PressOne.PH → Email submission
  • MindaNews → "Submit a lead"
  • ABS-CBN → Email or online form
HOW TO DO A FACT-CHECK?

params.text:
Instructions:

  1. Read/Watch the claim shown.
  2. Check if any trusted fact-checkers (Rappler, Vera Files, AFP, MindaNews, ABS-CBN Fact-Check, PressOne.PH) have investigated it.
  3. Provide the answer for the following:
    • Has it been fact-checked?
    • Who fact-checked it?
    • What was the verdict/rating (true, false, misleading)?

choices.question: Where did the image originally come from?
Do other reputable sources report the same thing?
Is the information available in fact-checking websites?
If you answered yes in the previous question, what was the verdict/rating? If no, choose not applicable
What action are you going to take?
answers: I will share the news to make others aware
I will warn others of this misinformation
I will treat the information as unverified or submit it for fact-checking

params.text:
Congratulations, Truth-Seeker!

You have successfully accomplished all adventures. See the next slides for your badge and certificate.

has shown remarkable courage, curiosity, and discernment throughout The Truth-Seeker’s Adventures. From sands to falls, this seeker followed the trail of truth and developed skills in evaluating sources, tracing information origins, and verifying claims — emerging as a Certified Truth-Seeker.
Awarded this day ___________________ of the year of disinformation.
